explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) compliance in the Baltic Sea; applies to tankers navigating near structured shipping lanes including the TSS South of Gedser and Kadetrinne; spatial anchor confirmed by proximity to multiple designated routes.
Operational Protocol Rationale: Tankers operating under engine propulsion in open waters near busy Baltic shipping corridors typically maintain straight, steady trajectories along predefined routes to comply with collision avoidance regulations and traffic flow management. The observed vessel exhibits stable speed, consistent course over ground, and tight alignment between heading and motion direction—hallmarks of autopilot-assisted transit along fixed maritime pathways. This behavior is expected for medium-sized tankers (100–150 m length, 4–6 m draught) transiting high-density areas where predictable movement ensures navigational safety. A curved trajectory or maneuvering intent would contradict the kinematic stability and route linearity seen here. Given that the surrounding context includes major traffic lanes and the vessel shows no deviation in propulsion or heading, continuing a linear path via time-proportional interpolation is the most operationally sound assumption, ruling out abrupt turns or drift.
'''
